conversation.content: [frozen] Jesus Christ, Marcus, you can't be here—not bleeding all over my prep station at two in the morning when I have three hundred covers tomorrow.
[breathlessly] Please, Elena, I know how this looks but there's nowhere else I could go, and the bullet's still in there somewhere near my ribs.
The Marcus I knew five years ago was a sous chef who wanted to open a food truck, not someone who shows up shot in my kitchen. [sharp exhale]
[grimacing] Yeah well, the food truck didn't exactly work out, and certain people pay better than minimum wage for certain skills I apparently possess.
[hushed] You're dripping blood on imported marble that costs more than most people's cars, and if hotel security finds you here, we're both finished.
Just give me twenty minutes to stop the bleeding and I'll disappear again, I swear—you'll never have to see me after tonight. [labored breathing]
God, you're still the same selfish bastard, aren't you? Showing up when you need something, making it my problem, my risk, my career on the line.
[weakly] That's fair, completely fair, but Elena, if I pass out in an alley somewhere, they'll find me by morning and trace everything back.
[reluctantly] There's a first aid kit in the office, industrial grade, and I can get morphine from the executive chef's migraine stash if you need it.
No drugs, they make me sloppy, and whoever's looking for me won't stop just because I'm wounded—they're probably checking hospitals right now. [groans]
Who exactly is 'they,' Marcus? Because if you've brought cartel violence into my kitchen, into my life again, I need to know what I'm dealing with.
[exhausted laugh] Not cartel this time, just a very unhappy politician who didn't appreciate me declining his latest contract after taking the advance payment.
You took money and didn't finish the job? Christ, even I know that's basically signing your own death warrant in your line of work.
The target was a kid, Elena—seventeen years old, some witness to something—and I might be a killer but I'm not that far gone yet. [coughs]
[softer] So you do still have some lines you won't cross, that's oddly comforting to know after everything that's happened between us.
[struggling] Don't read too much into it, I'm still the disappointment who chose bullets over béchamel sauce, remember? This doesn't change anything.
[firmly] Shut up and let me look at the wound—if you die in my kitchen, the health inspector will have my head, noble intentions or not.
Always the practical one, even when patching up your ex who became everything you warned me against becoming. [winces] God, that hurts.
Hold still, this is going to hurt worse—and Marcus? After tonight, after I clean you up and send you out that service door, we're truly done.
[quietly] I know, Elena, I've always known that some mistakes can't be undone, some paths only lead further into darkness. [resigned sigh] Thank you.

scenario: A hired gun, wounded and on the run, seeks refuge in the high-end hotel kitchen where his ex-lover works as food service director.
